*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and that modification is in the **best interests of the child.**

*G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and that modification is in the **best interests of the child.**

*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31*.proposition: Additionally, *G.L. c. 208, § 31* defines legal and physical custody, providing that the court must evaluate whether continued shared custody serves the child’s best interests in light of current circumstances.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a modification of custody is justified where changed circumstances significantly affect the child’s welfare.  *See* **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); **Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion is a removal/relocation case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post-judgment modification of custody based on changed circumstances. The court discusses the best-interests and “real advantage” standards for removal, but it does not articulate or apply a rule that a modification of custody is justified where changed circumstances significantly affect the child’s welfare. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification/changed-circumstances proposition stated.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)….”}

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a modification of custody is justified where changed circumstances significantly affect the child’s welfare.  *See* **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); **Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a custody-modification standard case. The opinion focuses on interpreting “cause shown” as a best-interests standard for relocation where there is joint physical custody; it does not discuss when a change in custody is justified or adopt a “changed circumstances significantly affecting the child’s welfare” test for modifying custody. The ALI passage the court quotes concerns relocation as a substantial change in circumstances, not the Massachusetts standard for custody modification generally.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]… (4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests….’”

**Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that a modification of custody is justified where changed circumstances significantly affect the child’s welfare.  *See* **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); **Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
**Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for an initial custody award in a divorce, not modification of an existing custody order based on changed circumstances. It reiterates that the governing principle is the child’s welfare and that all relevant factors must be weighed, but it does not discuss ‘changed circumstances’ or when a modification of custody is justified. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modification of custody based on changed circumstances.
**Bouchard v. Bouchard**, 12 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Health or medical deterioration of a parent can constitute a material change warranting modification when the parent’s capacity to meet the child’s needs is impacted.  *See* **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); **Ellis v. Ellis**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1996).
**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenthal v. Maney deals with relocation and modification of custody based on a claimed material and substantial change in circumstances, but the alleged changes involve the mother’s relocation, work schedule, and temporary custody orders—not health or medical deterioration of a parent. The court never discusses parental health decline, medical incapacity, or their impact on the ability to meet the child’s needs as a basis for modification. Thus, Rosenthal does not provide authority for the specific proposition that health or medical deterioration of a parent can constitute a material change warranting modification.
**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”

**Ellis v. Ellis**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 10.proposition: Health or medical deterioration of a parent can constitute a material change warranting modification when the parent’s capacity to meet the child’s needs is impacted.  *See* **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); **Ellis v. Ellis**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1996).

**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840\.proposition: Courts emphasize that the best interests of the child remain the paramount concern.  *See* **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840–841 (2003).
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840\.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly traces the history of the “best interests of the child” standard in Massachusetts custody law and reaffirms that it is the governing, paramount consideration in custody determinations. It cites earlier authority stating that the “best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern” and explains that statutory factors in G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a) guide but do not replace that overarching best-interests standard.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834, 840\.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)… The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider….”}

**Mandel v. Mandel**, 74 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The relevant inquiry balances the child’s health, safety, emotional development, and stability.  *See* **Mandel v. Mandel**, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 348 (2009); **M.C. v. T.K.**, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).
**Mandel v. Mandel**, 74 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case concerns allocation of college expenses under a merged separation agreement, not custody or visitation standards. While it adopts a multi-factor, equitable "reasonableness" test for college expenses (including financial resources and educational needs), it does not articulate a best-interests framework balancing a child’s health, safety, emotional development, and stability. Thus, citing Mandel for that specific proposition misstates its holding and focus.
**Mandel v. Mandel**, 74 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether college expenses are reasonable, courts have appropriately considered ‘all relevant equitable factors.’… These factors include ‘the financial resources of both parents, the standard of living the child would have enjoyed if the marriage had not been dissolved, the financial resources of the child, ... the cost of the school, the programs offered at the school, the child’s scholastic aptitude, how the school meets the child’s goals, and the benefits the child will receive from attending the school.’”

**M.C. v. T.K.**, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).proposition: The relevant inquiry balances the child’s health, safety, emotional development, and stability.  *See* **Mandel v. Mandel**, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 348 (2009); **M.C. v. T.K.**, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).
**M.C. v. T.K.**, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on child support calculations in a shared physical custody, high‑income setting and the inappropriateness of income equalization. It does not articulate a generalized “relevant inquiry” that balances the child’s health, safety, emotional development, and stability; instead it discusses standards of living and reasonable needs in the context of support. Thus it does not support the specific best‑interests balancing proposition claimed.
**M.C. v. T.K.**, 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Because the judge made no finding that the mother was unable to provide for the child’s reasonable needs while the child was in her care, in a manner consistent with a standard of living appropriate to a parent earning at least $150,000 per year, and because the evidence does not support an implied finding that the standard of living the child experienced at her mother’s home was grossly inferior to that which she enjoyed while with her father, the child support award did not have a factual basis.”

**Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App..proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction to make such modifications as justice requires.  *See* **Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
**Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns valuation of a sole proprietorship, treatment of income for support, claims of double-dipping, and a later complaint for modification based on changed circumstances. It applies the standard that modification requires a demonstrated material change in circumstances and that the degree of change is within the trial judge’s discretion; it does not discuss or rely on any concept of the court’s ‘continuing jurisdiction’ to modify judgments as justice requires. The proposition about continuing jurisdiction is therefore not supported by this case.
**Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In considering Joyce’s argument on appeal, we are mindful of our standard of review. As stated in Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26-27 (1981): ‘In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.’”}

**Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812.proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction to make such modifications as justice requires.  *See* **Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
**Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812.support_reasoning: This opinion deals with standards for allowing removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and reverses and remands because the trial judge applied too narrow a best-interests analysis. It does not discuss the court’s continuing or ongoing jurisdiction to modify prior orders “as justice requires,” nor does it reference any general continuing jurisdiction principle. The cited proposition about continuing jurisdiction likely comes from Champion v. Champion, not from Hale itself.
**Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812.relevant_excerpt: We reverse so much of the judgment as prohibits the wife from removing the minor children to California and remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion. We do not purport to determine the outcome. As more than a year has elapsed since the original hearing and circumstances may have changed in the meantime, such proceedings shall include the hearing of additional evidence if either party or the judge so elects, and shall also include a report of a qualified investigator if the judge should, in his discretion, determine that such a report would be helpful.

**Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (19.proposition: Where continuation of a shared custody plan would place undue responsibility, risk, or anxiety on the minor child, modification is warranted to preserve the child’s welfare.  *See* **Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
**Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion affirms that custody decisions must be guided by the welfare of the child and upholds an order eliminating the mother’s visitation because her conduct was harming the child. However, the case does not involve a shared or joint custody plan being modified; it concerns an initial custody award (after temporary orders) that vests custody solely in the father and stepmother. The court does not frame its ruling in terms of modifying a shared custody arrangement due to undue responsibility, risk, or anxiety on the child, so it only generally supports the child‑welfare principle, not the specific proposition as stated.
**Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The period of time covered by the several modifications of the court order granting the mother visitation rights coincided with a period of increasing differences between the parents over the visitations as they affected the child. There were captures and recaptures of the child in New York and Boston in circumstances which were harmful to the child and which caused emotional and physical reactions in the child commensurate with these distresses… At the conclusion of the hearing… the judge awarded custody of the child to the father and stepmother, with no rights of visitation by the mother.”

**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.proposition: Where continuation of a shared custody plan would place undue responsibility, risk, or anxiety on the minor child, modification is warranted to preserve the child’s welfare.  *See* **Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings on the impact of domestic violence when making or continuing a shared/joint custody arrangement, particularly where there is a 209A restraining order. It does not state or hold that modification is warranted when shared custody places undue responsibility, risk, or anxiety on the child; nor does it discuss changing an existing shared custody plan on that basis. The case is about remanding for further findings, not articulating a standard for modification of a shared custody arrangement based on the child’s anxiety or burden.
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody … the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ … We agree with the Appeals Court that such written findings should also be made attending specifically to the effects of domestic violence on the child and the appropriateness of the joint custody award in light of those effects.”
